Federated Learning for Sparse Principal Component Analysis

Abstract

In the rapidly evolving realm of machine learning, algorithm effectiveness often faces limitations due to data quality and availability. Traditional approaches grapple with data sharing due to legal and privacy concerns. The federated learning framework addresses this challenge. Federated learning is a decentralized approach where model training occurs on client sides, preserving privacy by keeping data localized. Instead of sending raw data to a central server, only model updates are exchanged, enhancing data security. We apply this framework to Sparse Principal Component Analysis (SPCA) in this work. SPCA aims to attain sparse component loadings while maximizing data variance for improved interpretability. Beside the â„“1subscriptâ„“1\ell_{1} norm regularization term in conventional SPCA, we add a smoothing function to facilitate gradient-based optimization methods. Moreover, in order to improve computational efficiency, we introduce a least squares approximation to original SPCA. This enables analytic solutions on the optimization processes, leading to substantial computational improvements. Within the federated framework, we formulate SPCA as a consensus optimization problem, which can be solved using the Alternating Direction Method of Multipliers (ADMM). Our extensive experiments involve both IID and non-IID random features across various data owners. Results on synthetic and public datasets affirm the efficacy of our federated SPCA approach.

Index Terms:
ADMM, Consensus Learning, Federated Learning, Sparse Principal Component Analysis

I Introduction

In the rapidly evolving field of machine learning, the effectiveness of algorithms often hinges on the quantity, quality and accessibility of data. Unfortunately, due to legal and privacy concerns, data sharing for the purpose of enhancing machine learning is typically prohibited. To address this challenge, the Federated Learning (FL) framework was introduced [1]. Federated learning represents a decentralized approach, where model training takes place on client-side devices, ensuring privacy by keeping data localized. Instead of transmitting raw data to a central server, only model updates are exchanged, thereby bolstering data security. This constitutes a distributed learning process.

In general, many machine learning tasks can be framed as optimization problems, and distributed optimization techniques have been well-developed. It is inherent in the nature of the federated learning framework to have applications across various machine learning algorithms, including linear and nonlinear support vector machines, as well as deep learning. In this context, we will introduce two innovative approaches: Federated Smoothing Sparse Principal Component Analysis (FSSPCA) and Federated Approximation Sparse Principal Component Analysis (FASPCA). These methodologies have been specifically crafted to tackle the challenge of Sparse Principal Component Analysis (SPCA) within a distributed framework.

Principal Component Analysis (PCA), introduced by Pearson [2] in 1901, has been extensively used in various applications, from dimension reduction to anomaly detection [3]. The goal of PCA is to find an orthogonal basis that maximizes the variance of the original data when projected onto this basis. Formatting this as an optimization problem, we have

s.t.formulae-sequenceğ‘ ğ‘¡\displaystyle s.t. wâŠ¤â€‹w=I,superscriptwtopwI\displaystyle\quad\textbf{w}^{\top}\textbf{w}=\textbf{I},

where Aâˆˆâ„nÃ—dAsuperscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘‘\textbf{A}\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times d} is a mean-centered dataset with nğ‘›n instances and dğ‘‘d features and âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥F\|\cdot\|_{F} represents the Frobenius norm of a matrix. The matrix wâˆˆâ„dÃ—rwsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘Ÿ\textbf{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times r} consists of rğ‘Ÿr principal components, which are the eigenvectors corresponding to the rğ‘Ÿr largest eigenvalues of the covariance matrix of A. Alternatively, PCA can be reformulated into a minimization problem:

minwâˆˆâ„dÃ—rsubscriptwsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘Ÿ\displaystyle\min_{\textbf{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times r}} â€–Aâˆ’AwwâŠ¤â€–F2superscriptsubscriptnormAsuperscriptAwwtopğ¹2\displaystyle\quad\|\textbf{A}-\textbf{A}\textbf{w}\textbf{w}^{\top}\|_{F}^{2}
s.t.formulae-sequenceğ‘ ğ‘¡\displaystyle s.t. wâŠ¤â€‹w=I.superscriptwtopwI\displaystyle\quad\textbf{w}^{\top}\textbf{w}=\textbf{I}.

This reformulation can be interpreted as minimization of the reconstruction error, which aims to represent data in fewer dimensions, while still approximating the original data as closely as possible.

However, traditional PCA often yields dense component loadings, making the results difficult to interpret. To address this issue, Sparse PCA (SPCA) was proposed [4], aiming to find loadings that are more interpretable due to their sparsity.

In addition to its conventional applications, PCA is also harnessed in FL frameworks to enable collaborative computation without data centralization [5]. SPCA has yet to be fully adapted and studied within this emerging framework, suggesting a novel direction for advancement. In this work, we focus on a distributed setting in which various data owners aim to jointly train a model without sharing their own data with each other. Suppose that the objective function fâ€‹(w)ğ‘“wf(\textbf{w}) can be decomposed into Kğ¾K parts as fâ€‹(w)=âˆ‘i=1Kfiâ€‹(w)ğ‘“wsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ¾subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–wf(\textbf{w})=\sum_{i=1}^{K}f_{i}(\textbf{w}), where Kğ¾K is the number of data owners and each fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} is a local objective function, which involves only the data of the iğ‘–ith owner. The minimization of fâ€‹(w)ğ‘“wf(\textbf{w}) can be reformulated as the following global variable consensus optimization problem [6]:

minw1,â‹¯,wK,zsubscriptsubscriptw1â‹¯subscriptwğ¾z\displaystyle\min_{\textbf{w}_{1},\cdots,\textbf{w}_{K},\textbf{z}} âˆ‘i=1Kfiâ€‹(wi)superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ¾subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptwğ‘–\displaystyle\quad\sum_{i=1}^{K}f_{i}(\textbf{w}_{i})
s.t.formulae-sequenceğ‘ ğ‘¡\displaystyle s.t. wi=z,âˆ€i,subscriptwğ‘–zfor-allğ‘–\displaystyle\quad\textbf{w}_{i}=\textbf{z},\forall i,

where z is the common global variable and each wisubscriptwğ‘–\textbf{w}_{i} is the local variable for each data owner. In the framework of FL, the alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM) algorithm, a widely adopted approach in such context, can be employed.

The ADMM iterative algorithm within the framework of FL consists of two parts: the masterâ€™s and the workersâ€™. Suppose that there exists a central server, called the master, responsible for updating the global variable z and integrating all local variables wisubscriptwğ‘–\textbf{w}_{i}. Each data owner employs a device known as the worker, tasked with updating the local variable wisubscriptwğ‘–\textbf{w}_{i} by minimizing the objective fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} using its own data. Following the update of wisubscriptwğ‘–\textbf{w}_{i}, each worker sends the locally updated variable wisubscriptwğ‘–\textbf{w}_{i} to the master. Consequently, the master integrates wi,âˆ€isubscriptwğ‘–for-allğ‘–\textbf{w}_{i},\forall i, to update z, and then distributes the globally updated parameter z to all workers. The goal of this iterative process is to compute the sparse loadings within the FL framework.

II RELATED WORK

II-A Sparse Principal Component Analysis

In recent years, numerous approaches for SPCA have been introduced [7]. Inspired by lasso regression, Jolliffe et al. [8] proposed SCOTLASS, which added an â„“1subscriptâ„“1\ell_{1}-norm term to the original PCA problem. Unlike SCOTLASS, Zou et al. [4] added an â„“1subscriptâ„“1\ell_{1}-norm term or an elastic net term by

minw,vâˆˆâ„dÃ—rsubscriptwvsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘Ÿ\displaystyle\min_{\textbf{w},\textbf{v}\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times r}} â€–Aâˆ’AwvâŠ¤â€–F2+âˆ‘i=1r(Î»â€‹â€–viâ€–22+Î³iâ€‹â€–viâ€–1)superscriptsubscriptnormAsuperscriptAwvtopğ¹2superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘Ÿğœ†superscriptsubscriptnormsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘–22subscriptğ›¾ğ‘–subscriptnormsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘–1\displaystyle\quad\|\textbf{A}-\textbf{A}\textbf{w}\textbf{v}^{\top}\|_{F}^{2}+\sum_{i=1}^{r}\left(\lambda\|v_{i}\|_{2}^{2}+\gamma_{i}\|v_{i}\|_{1}\right) (1)
s.t.formulae-sequenceğ‘ ğ‘¡\displaystyle s.t. wâŠ¤â€‹w=I,superscriptwtopwI\displaystyle\quad\textbf{w}^{\top}\textbf{w}=\textbf{I},

where Aâˆˆâ„nÃ—dAsuperscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘‘\textbf{A}\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times d} is a mean-centered dataset of nğ‘›n instances with dğ‘‘d features, rğ‘Ÿr is the number of desired loadings, visubscriptğ‘£ğ‘–v_{i} is the iğ‘–ith column of v, and Î»,Î³i>0ğœ†subscriptğ›¾ğ‘–0\lambda,\gamma_{i}>0 are trade-off parameters. They solved this problem by iterating the sub-problems of w and v alternately. One advantage of this approach is that it decomposes the orthogonality constraint and the non-smooth â„“1subscriptâ„“1\ell_{1}-norm term into two sub-problems. Thus, each sub-problem is easier to solve than the original problem. Some methods tackle SPCA by relying on power methods. Journee et al. [9] proposed the generalized power method (Gpower) to extract a single sparse dominant principal component or more components at once with the â„“0subscriptâ„“0\ell_{0}-norm or the â„“1subscriptâ„“1\ell_{1}-norm. Ge et al. [10] proposed distributed privacy-preserving SPCA to compute SPCA in a distributed optimization framework by the power iteration with differential privacy.

II-B ADMM

The Alternating Direction Method of Multipliers (ADMM) is an optimization method commonly used in federated learning. It was first proposed in the 1970s by Glowinski [11] and Gabay et al. [12]. In 2011, Boyd et al. [6] proposed a detailed review of this algorithm, making it widely adopted in decentralized machine learning [13, 14, 15]. Furthermore, by combining cryptographic tools such as multiparty computation [16, 17], and zero-knowledge proof [18], the ADMM algorithm can protect data privacy when applied to federated learning models [19, 20]

Some studies employed the ADMM algorithm on sparse PCA. Ma and Shiqian [21] solved the DSPCA by the ADMM algorithm. Vu et al. [22] viewed the SPCA problem as an optimization problem on the Fantope and then used the ADMM algorithm to solve it. Instead of the convex penalty term â„“1subscriptâ„“1\ell_{1}-norm, Hajinezhad and Hong [23] used non-convex penalties to obtain sparse loading by the non-convex ADMM algorithm. Tan et al. [24] considered the SPCA problem as an optimization problem on the Stiefel manifold and then used the ADMM algorithm to solve it. Despite the widespread use of ADMM in SPCA, these studies have not yet ventured into its application within the context of federated learning.

II-C Smoothing function

When dealing with optimization problems, deriving closed-form solutions is often not practical for the majority of cases. In such scenarios, it is a common approach to use gradient-based methods such as Newtonâ€™s method, stochastic gradient descent, and Adam method [25]. Nevertheless, if the problem lacks differentiability, it remains unfeasible to employ these gradient-based methods. For example, because of the â„“1subscriptâ„“1\ell_{1}-norm, problem (1) is not differentiable at 0. To address this issue, a common approach is to employ a smoothing function as a replacement for the non-differentiable part [26, 27, 28]. This technique is also widely adopted in the field of machine learning and deep learning. For instance, the sigmoid function is often used to substitute the rectified linear unit [29, 30]. However, to our knowledge, using smoothing functions to replace the â„“1subscriptâ„“1\ell_{1}-norm in the SPCA has not been explored. In our proposed method, we employ a smoothing function to substitute the â„“1subscriptâ„“1\ell_{1}-norm, thus enabling the utilization of gradient-based methods to the SPCA problem.

III Proposed model

III-A Federated Smoothing Sparse Principal Component Analysis

However, we observe that the algorithm struggles to converge when applied to the federated learning problem. III-B Line-search method on the Stiefel Manifold

For each worker, with fixed uisubscriptuğ‘–\textbf{u}_{i} and z, the optimization of â„’ÏSâ€‹({wi,ui}i=1K,z)superscriptsubscriptâ„’ğœŒğ‘†superscriptsubscriptsubscriptwğ‘–subscriptuğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ¾z\mathcal{L}_{\rho}^{S}(\{\textbf{w}_{i},\textbf{u}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{K},\textbf{z}) over wisubscriptwğ‘–\textbf{w}_{i} is given by

minwiâˆˆâ„³rsubscriptsubscriptwğ‘–subscriptâ„³ğ‘Ÿ\displaystyle\min_{\textbf{w}_{i}\in\mathcal{M}_{r}} â€–Aiâˆ’Aiâ€‹wiâ€‹wiâŠ¤â€–F2+Î»1â€‹râ€‹(wi)superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscriptAğ‘–superscriptAğ‘–subscriptwğ‘–superscriptsubscriptwğ‘–topğ¹2subscriptğœ†1ğ‘Ÿsubscriptwğ‘–\displaystyle\|\textbf{A}^{i}-\textbf{A}^{i}\textbf{w}_{i}\textbf{w}_{i}^{\top}\|_{F}^{2}+\lambda_{1}r(\textbf{w}_{i}) (14)
+âŸ¨ui,wiâŸ©+Ï2â€‹â€–wiâˆ’zâ€–F2.subscriptuğ‘–subscriptwğ‘–ğœŒ2superscriptsubscriptnormsubscriptwğ‘–zğ¹2\displaystyle+\langle\textbf{u}_{i},\textbf{w}_{i}\rangle+\frac{\rho}{2}\|\textbf{w}_{i}-\textbf{z}\|_{F}^{2}.

Following Tan et al. [24], (14) can be solved using the line-search method on the Stiefel Manifold.

The primary objective of the line search method is to find a descent direction in which our objective function decreases. A direct approach is to take the opposite direction of the gradient as the descent direction. However, since the objective function (14) is restricted to the Stiefel manifold, its gradient cannot be directly computed through partial differentiation.

To address optimization on the Stiefel manifold â„³rsubscriptâ„³ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{M}_{r}, we introduce some geometries over the Stiefel manifold â„³rsubscriptâ„³ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{M}_{r}. First, the tangent space to â„³rsubscriptâ„³ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{M}_{r} at wâˆˆâ„³rwsubscriptâ„³ğ‘Ÿ\textbf{w}\in\mathcal{M}_{r}, denoted by Twâ€‹â„³rsubscriptğ‘‡wsubscriptâ„³ğ‘ŸT_{\textbf{w}}\mathcal{M}_{r}, is defined as

Twâ€‹â„³r={zâˆˆâ„dÃ—r|zâŠ¤â€‹w+wâŠ¤â€‹z=0}.subscriptğ‘‡wsubscriptâ„³ğ‘Ÿconditional-setzsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptztopwsuperscriptwtopz0\displaystyle T_{\textbf{w}}\mathcal{M}_{r}=\{\textbf{z}\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times r}|\textbf{z}^{\top}\textbf{w}+\textbf{w}^{\top}\textbf{z}=\textbf{0}\}.

Given a smooth function fğ‘“f on Euclidean space, let fÂ¯Â¯ğ‘“\bar{f} denote the restriction of fğ‘“f to the Stiefel manifold. Define sym(A) = 12â€‹(A+AâŠ¤)12AsuperscriptAtop\frac{1}{2}(\textbf{A}+\textbf{A}^{\top}), for any square matrix A. Suppose we have the gradient âˆ‡fâ€‹(w)âˆ‡ğ‘“w\nabla f(\textbf{w}) of fğ‘“f at wâˆˆâ„³rwsubscriptâ„³ğ‘Ÿ\textbf{w}\in\mathcal{M}_{r}. Then the gradient of fÂ¯(W)\bar{f}(\textbf{W)}, denoted by gradfâ€‹(w)ğ‘“wf(\textbf{w}), is equal to the orthogonal projection of âˆ‡fâ€‹(w)âˆ‡ğ‘“w\nabla f(\textbf{w}) onto Twâ€‹â„³rsubscriptğ‘‡wsubscriptâ„³ğ‘ŸT_{\textbf{w}}\mathcal{M}_{r}, that is,

gradâ€‹fâ€‹(w)=PTwâ€‹â„³râ€‹(âˆ‡fâ€‹(w)),gradğ‘“wsubscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘‡wsubscriptâ„³ğ‘Ÿâˆ‡ğ‘“w\displaystyle\text{grad}f(\textbf{w})=P_{T_{\textbf{w}}\mathcal{M}_{r}}(\nabla f(\textbf{w})), (15)

where PTwâ€‹â„³rsubscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘‡wsubscriptâ„³ğ‘ŸP_{T_{\textbf{w}}\mathcal{M}_{r}} is denoted the orthogonal projection function onto Twâ€‹â„³rsubscriptğ‘‡wsubscriptâ„³ğ‘ŸT_{\textbf{w}}\mathcal{M}_{r} at wâˆˆâ„³rwsubscriptâ„³ğ‘Ÿ\textbf{w}\in\mathcal{M}_{r} by

PTwâ€‹â„³râ€‹(X)=Xâˆ’wÂ symâ€‹(wâŠ¤â€‹X),subscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘‡wsubscriptâ„³ğ‘ŸXXwÂ symsuperscriptwtopX\displaystyle P_{T_{\textbf{w}}\mathcal{M}_{r}}(\textbf{X})=\textbf{X}-\textbf{w}\text{ sym}(\textbf{w}^{\top}\textbf{X}), (16)

for any Xâˆˆâ„dÃ—rXsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘Ÿ\textbf{X}\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times r}.

After obtaining the gradient of the objective function, which is restricted to the Stiefel manifold, we can proceed to construct the descent direction ğœ»=âˆ’gradâ€‹fâ€‹(w)ğœ»gradğ‘“w\boldsymbol{\zeta}=-\text{grad}f(\textbf{w}). Additionally, the use of conjugate gradient [24, 31] can improve the convergence speed at workersâ€™ stage. With step size Î¸ğœƒ\theta, we can move w along the descent direction ğœ»ğœ»\boldsymbol{\zeta} as wnâ€‹eâ€‹xâ€‹t=w+Î¸â€‹ğœ»subscriptwğ‘›ğ‘’ğ‘¥ğ‘¡wğœƒğœ»\textbf{w}_{next}=\textbf{w}+\theta\boldsymbol{\zeta}. Rwâ€‹(Î¸â€‹ğœ»)=qfâ€‹(w+Î¸â€‹ğœ»),subscriptğ‘…wğœƒğœ»qfwğœƒğœ»\displaystyle R_{\textbf{w}}(\theta\boldsymbol{\zeta})=\text{qf}(\textbf{w}+\theta\boldsymbol{\zeta}), (17)

III-C Deflation method for FSSPCA

FSSPCA can compute multiple loadings simultaneously. Drawing upon the deflation technique for SPCA proposed by Mackey [34], we outline the deflation scheme in Algorithm 4.

RwGâ€‹(Î¸â€‹ğœ»)=Gâˆ’1â€‹qfâ€‹(Gâ€‹(w+Î¸â€‹ğœ»)).superscriptsubscriptğ‘…wGğœƒğœ»superscriptG1qfGwğœƒğœ»\displaystyle R_{\textbf{w}}^{\textbf{G}}(\theta\boldsymbol{\zeta})=\sqrt{\textbf{G}}^{-1}\text{qf}\left(\sqrt{\textbf{G}}(\textbf{w}+\theta\boldsymbol{\zeta})\right). (22)

Thus, replacing the projection in Algorithm 3 with (21) and retraction with Algorithm 5, we manage to extend Algorithm 3 from the Stiefel manifold to the generalized Stiefel manifold.

III-D Federated Approximation Sparse Principal Component Analysis

In the previous subsection, we introduced how to tackle the conventional SPCA problem within the federated learning system. However, we observed that employing gradient-based methods to compute rğ‘Ÿr loadings simultaneously could incur significant computational costs. Regarding the scenarios that only a single or the first few loadings are desired, we propose an alternative approach using a least squares approximation to alleviate the computational burden. The problem is formulated as

minwâˆˆâ„dÃ—1subscriptwsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘1\displaystyle\min_{\textbf{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times 1}} â€–Aâˆ’AwwâŠ¤â€–22+Î»â€‹â€–wâ€–1superscriptsubscriptnormAsuperscriptAwwtop22ğœ†subscriptnormw1\displaystyle\quad\|\textbf{A}-\textbf{A}\textbf{w}\textbf{w}^{\top}\|_{2}^{2}+\lambda\|\textbf{w}\|_{1} (23)

[3, 36], we propose the Federated Approximation SPCA (FASPCA) to solve this problem. Following Yang [37], we utilize the projection approximation technique to transform (23) into the subsequent form,

IV Experiment

In the federated learning framework, non-IID (non-Independently and Identically Distributed) data distribution across nodes is a critical concern, as it can significantly reduce both the accuracy and convergence rate [32, 38]. Real-world scenarios often exhibit data skews and imbalances among participating workers due to a variety of factors such as user behavior, data collection methods, and other domain-specific influences. To evaluate the performance of our proposed methods, FSSPCA and FASPCA, we conducted experiments on four distinct datasets: IID synthetic data, non-IID synthetic data, IID real data, and non-IID real data. These evaluations were performed on a universally accessible laptop with an Intel Core i5-8250U CPU and 8 GB of RAM, operating without the assistance of a GPU. All algorithms were implemented using the Python programming environment.

IV-A Experiments on IID synthetic data

In the following experiments, we assess FSSPCA and FASPCA using synthetic data sampled from a zero-mean multivariate normal distribution with a covariance matrix ğšºâˆˆâ„500Ã—500ğšºsuperscriptâ„500500\boldsymbol{\Sigma}\in\mathbb{R}^{500\times 500} that consists of sparse eigenvectors and split the dataset into Kğ¾K parts to evaluate the performance of our methods in different distributed systems. Following [9, 24], we construct ğšº=VDVâŠ¤ğšºsuperscriptVDVtop\boldsymbol{\Sigma}=\textbf{V}\textbf{D}\textbf{V}^{\top}, where Vâˆˆâ„500Ã—500Vsuperscriptâ„500500\textbf{V}\in\mathbb{R}^{500\times 500} is an orthogonal matrix whose columns are eigenvectors of ğšºğšº\boldsymbol{\Sigma} and Dâˆˆâ„500Ã—500Dsuperscriptâ„500500\textbf{D}\in\mathbb{R}^{500\times 500} is a diagonal matrix whose diagonal elements are eigenvalues of ğšºğšº\boldsymbol{\Sigma}. We set the first two columns of V as the ground truth for sparse loadings, specifically setting the first 10 elements of the first column and the second 10 elements of the second column to 110110\frac{1}{\sqrt{10}}, while all other elements are set to 0. The remaining columns of V are random samples from a uniform distribution over [0, 1). The first two eigenvalues of D are set to 400 and 300, respectively, and the rest are set to 1. Our aim is to recover the first two significant eigenvectors, denoted as Vâ€‹sâ€‹oâ€‹lVğ‘ ğ‘œğ‘™\textbf{V}{sol}, and performance is evaluated by the recovery error Ïµ=â€–zzâŠ¤âˆ’Vsâ€‹oâ€‹lâ€‹Vsâ€‹oâ€‹lâŠ¤â€–F2italic-ÏµsuperscriptsubscriptnormsuperscriptzztopsubscriptVğ‘ ğ‘œğ‘™superscriptsubscriptVğ‘ ğ‘œğ‘™topğ¹2\epsilon=\|\textbf{z}\textbf{z}^{\top}-\textbf{V}_{sol}\textbf{V}_{sol}^{\top}\|_{F}^{2}, where z is the outcome of our methods.

Firstly, we demonstrate that parameters from each worker become increasingly similar with each iteration to attain a consensus model parameter. To evaluate this, we set K=10ğ¾10K=10 and compute the pairwise cosine similarity of all workersâ€™ parameters, and then average their absolute values. Fig. 2 illustrates that with an increasing number of iterations, the average value approaches 1. In other words, the parameters from each worker will become more and more similar to each other, which satisfies the constraint of the prime problem for FASPCA (26) and FSSPCA (6).

Next, we split the synthetic dataset into Kğ¾K parts to evaluate the recovery error of our methods with different numbers of data owners, where K=1,3,5,10ğ¾13510K=1,3,5,10. As shown in Fig. 3, regardless of the value of Kğ¾K, as the Î»ğœ†\lambda or Î»1subscriptğœ†1\lambda_{1} increase, the recovery error approaches 0. In other words, our methods yield outcomes that closely resemble the ground truth Vsâ€‹oâ€‹lsubscriptVğ‘ ğ‘œğ‘™\textbf{V}_{sol}. Hence, we conclude that our proposed models FASPCA and FSSPCA are capable of obtaining sparse loadings under the FL framework.

IV-B Experiments on IID Real data

Wisconsin Diagnostic Breast Cancer Dataset (WDBC) [39] is a well-known dataset for the classification task. This dataset contains 569 instances with 31 features. The primary goal of SPCA is to identify important features. To evaluate the performance of our proposed models, we choose the last 30 features of WDBC, excluding the ID number. We augmented it with 800 randomly generated features from a uniform distribution over [0, 1) to create a new dataset WDBCâ‹†âˆˆâ„569Ã—830superscriptWDBCâ‹†superscriptâ„569830\text{WDBC}^{\star}\in\mathbb{R}^{569\times 830}. In the following experiments, our goal is to identify 2 sparse loadings. We demonstrate that our proposed models can effectively identify important features by shrinking the weights of the added random features to zero or close to zero.

Firstly, we show the effectiveness of adding the â„“1subscriptâ„“1\ell_{1}-norm smoothing terms for FSSPCA. As shown in Fig. 4, when Î»1=10subscriptğœ†110\lambda_{1}=10, which means that we activate the smoothing function term râ€‹(wi)ğ‘Ÿsubscriptwğ‘–r(\textbf{w}_{i}), the convergence behavior is far better than the case of Î»1=0subscriptğœ†10\lambda_{1}=0. That is to say, adding the â„“1subscriptâ„“1\ell_{1}-norm smoothing terms significantly improves convergence.

Since one of the primary purposes of SPCA is to facilitate interpretability through sparse loadings, we assess the result of the purposed methods. In Fig. 5, for both FASPCA and FSSPCA, we observed that all the weights associated with the added random features lie in [âˆ’0.1,0.1]0.10.1[-0.1,0.1]. Additionally, 27%percent\% and 35%percent\% of the weights corresponding to original features of FASPCA and FSSPCA fell within [âˆ’0.1,0.1]0.10.1[-0.1,0.1], respectively. Moreover, for iâˆˆ{1,2,â‹¯,10}ğ‘–12â‹¯10i\in\{1,2,\cdots,10\}, we noticed that the percentages of small values, falling within [âˆ’10i,10i]superscript10ğ‘–superscript10ğ‘–[-10^{i},10^{i}], of added random features are higher than the original features. These findings confirm that both FASPCA and FSSPCA provide more interpretable results and can effectively identify important features in the dataset.

As shown in Table I, no matter FASPCA or FSSPCA, the reconstruction errors of our proposed models are close to PCA and the â„“0subscriptâ„“0\ell_{0}-norm of our proposed models are less than PCA. Thus, our proposed model can indeed attain loading sparsity. Additionally, while FASPCA is faster in terms of computation time, FSSPCA requires fewer iterations, almost half that of FASPCA. In our experiments, we assume negligible transmission costs between workers and the master. However, in scenarios with significant transmission costs, FSSPCA may offer advantages over FASPCA.

IV-C Experiments on non-IID synthetic data

In the third experiment, we evaluate our proposed model on non-IID synthetic data. The data is generated in a manner similar to the IID synthetic dataset, with eigenvalues and the first two eigenvectors remaining consistent across all workers. However, for each worker, the remaining eigenvectors are uniquely generated as random samples from a normal distribution Nâ€‹(0,Ïƒi)ğ‘0subscriptğœğ‘–N(0,\sigma_{i}), and Ïƒisubscriptğœğ‘–\sigma_{i} is independently sampled from a uniform distribution over [0, 1) for each worker.

As demonstrated in Fig. 6, the trends observed in non-IID synthetic data are consistent with those in IID synthetic data. Specifically, as the number of iterations increases, the average value converges toward 1. This pattern demonstrates that the parameters from each worker become increasingly aligned, thereby meeting the constraints of the primary problems as defined for both FASPCA (26) and FSSPCA (6). Moreover, the recovery errors for FASPCA and FSSPCA were 0.0855 and 0.02466, respectively. Both of which are close to zero, indicating an effective approach towards the ground truth Vsâ€‹oâ€‹lsubscriptVğ‘ ğ‘œğ‘™\textbf{V}_{sol}. The robustness of our proposed methods in both IID and non-IID settings highlights their effectiveness and broad applicability within the federated learning framework.

IV-D Experiments on non-IID Real data

In the fourth experiment, we assess the performance of our proposed model on non-IID real data. Similar to Subsection B, we retain the last 30 features of the WDBC dataset, but introduce modifications to the additional 800 random features. These 800 features are now uniquely allocated to each participating worker. For each worker, the allocated features are generated using a normal distribution with a mean of zero and a variance sampled from a uniform distribution over [0, 1). The remaining features are rendered sparse, with 80% being exactly 0 and 20% non-zero values generated from a uniform distribution over [0, 1). With this generating scheme, each worker may return the local model with some non-zero weights associated with the allocated parts, while the other workers returning sparse results.

Referring to Fig. 7, it is evident that for both FASPCA and FSSPCA, the weights of the added random features fall within the range of [âˆ’0.01,0.01]0.010.01[-0.01,0.01]. In contrast, 55%percent\% of the original feature weights for FASPCA and 30%percent\% for FSSPCA lie within the [âˆ’0.1,0.1]0.10.1[-0.1,0.1] range. Moreover, for iğ‘–i in the set {1,2,â€¦,10}12â€¦10\{1,2,\ldots,10\}, the proportions of smaller values that fall within the bounds of [âˆ’10i,10i]superscript10ğ‘–superscript10ğ‘–[-10^{i},10^{i}] are notably higher for the added random features compared with the original features. Another critical aspect to consider is the reconstruction error. The reconstruction error for PCA itself stands at 236.4406, while for FASPCA and FSSPCA, it stands at 242.4147 and 236.9857, respectively. These close values indicate that both FASPCA and FSSPCA perform comparably to traditional PCA. These results show that both FASPCA and FSSPCA work well in identifying important features and provide easily interpretable outcomes, even when applied to the non-IID dataset.

V Conclusion and Future Work

We have introduced two innovative approaches: Federated Approximation Sparse Principal Component Analysis (FASPCA) and Federated Smoothing Sparse Principal Component Analysis (FSSPCA). These methods are designed to tackle the Sparse Principal Component Analysis (SPCA) challenge within a distributed framework. They enable model training on client-side devices, preserving privacy by keeping data localized. Instead of transmitting raw data to a central server, only model updates are exchanged, significantly enhancing data security. We have also incorporated the least squares approximation in the PCA component to reduce computational complexity without compromising accuracy. In specific scenarios, such as anomaly detection, where only a single loading is required, FASPCA demonstrates remarkable efficiency due to its rapid computation. When multiple loadings are necessary, the deflation technique is employed to map the data to the orthogonal complement space of the leading component. Our experiments, conducted on synthetic and WDBCâ‹†superscriptWDBCâ‹†\text{WDBC}^{\star} datasets, underscore the exceptional performance of both FASPCA and FSSPCA in obtaining sparse loadings within distributed systems. Furthermore, these methods effectively extract crucial features while accommodating non-IID (non-Independently and Identically Distributed) random features.

In our future research endeavors, we intend to explore the integration of cryptographic techniques, such as differential privacy, to further enhance data security and privacy within the federated learning framework.
